introduction.p: Study of the rate of change of position x gave us the velocity v_x. We apply the same methods to study the rate of change of v_x. Therefore, we get two ways to look at this rate - (1) graphically, we use the slope of the v_x versus t plot, and (2) analytically, using Calculus, we take the derivative of v_x. We call the rate of change of v_x the acceleration and denote it by a_x.

p.p:
Alternately, we us the following definition based on graphical method:
a_x = \text{ slope of tangent to }v_x\text{ versus }t.
If the plot of v_x versus t is linear, i.e., a straight line, then the tangent line is same as the line of the plot, hence a_x is just the slope of the line.
But, if the plot of v_x versus t is curved, then you would draw a tangent line at the instant of interest, and then compute the slope of the tangent line to get a_x .

subsubsection.title: (Calculus) Definition of Acceleration

p.alert: Going from acceleration to change in velocity

subsubsection.p: The inverse problem of obtaining change in velocity, \Delta v_x, from a known acceleration over an interval, a_x(t) , is similar problem of going from v_x to \Delta x. Therefore, the math is similar with same two ways of looking at it.

sidebyside.p:
The inverse of Eq. gives the change in velocity \Delta v_x = v_{f,x} - v_{i,x} when we integrate acceleration a_x .
\Delta v_x \equiv v_{f,x} - v_{i,x} = \int_{t_i}^{t_f}\ a_x(t)\, dt.

Similar to the derivative, there is an alternative graphical way to calculate the integral. We compute the area bertween the a_x versus t plot line/curve and the a_x=0 line, which is just the t axis line.

exercise.title: Using slope of v_x to compute a_x

statement.p: From the v_x versus t plot, find a_x at the following instants: (a) t = 1\text{ sec}, (b) t = 3\text{ sec} , and (c) t = 3.75\text{ sec} .

solution.p: (a) The v_x versus t plot through the time when t = 1\text{ sec} is a straight line. Therefore, a_x will simply be slope of this part of the plot. The slope of this line is clearly zero. Therefore, a_x (\text{at }t=1\text{ sec}) = 0.

(b) The v_x versus t plot through the time when t = 3\text{ sec} is a straight line. Therefore, a_x will simply be slope of this part of the plot. The slope of this line is obtained by picking two points on the line between t = 2\text{ sec} and t = 3.5\text{ sec}. We pick points at t = 2\text{ sec} and t = 3\text{ sec} to obtain
a_x = \dfrac{0 - 4\text{ m/s}}{3\text{ s}-2\text{ s}} = -4\text{ m/s}^2.

(b) The v_x versus t plot through the time when t = 3.75\text{ sec} is a straight line. Therefore, a_x will simply be slope of this part of the plot. The slope of this line is obtained by picking two points on the line between t = 3.5\text{ sec} and t = 4.0\text{ sec}. We pick points at t = 3.5\text{ sec} and t = 4\text{ sec} to obtain
a_x = \dfrac{0 - (-2)\text{ m/s}}{4\text{ s}-3.5\text{ s}} = 4\text{ m/s}^2.

exercise.title: Compute \Delta v_x from a_x versus t plot

statement.p: A ball is initially ( t=0 ) moving at v_x = 3\text{ m/s}. The acceleration of the ball at different times are as shown in the a_x versus t plot. Find v_x at (a) t = 1\text{ sec} , (b) t = 2\text{ sec} , and (c) t = 4\text{ sec} .

solution.p:
(a) From the area-under-curve we can find the change in v_x during t= 0 to t = 1\text{ sec}. Adding this change to the v_x at t= 0 will give us the v_x at t=1\text{ sec}.
\Delta v_x = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 4 \times 1 = 2\text{ m/s}.
Therefore, v_x at t=1\text{ sec}:
v_x(\text{ at }t=1\text{ sec }) = v_x(\text{ at }t=0\ ) + \Delta v_x = 5\text{ m/s}.

(b) The area-under-the-curve during t= 1\text{ sec} to t = 2\text{ sec} is zero. Hence the velocity does not change over this interval, i.e., \Delta v_x = 0 .
v_x(\text{ at }t=2\text{ sec }) = v_x(\text{ at }t=1\text{ sec } ) + \Delta v_x = 5\text{ m/s}.

(c) From the area-under-curve we can find the change in t= 2\text{ sec} to t = 4\text{ sec}. Adding this change to the v_x at t= 2\text{ sec} will give us the v_x at t=4\text{ sec}.
\Delta v_x = -2 \times 4 = -8\text{ m/s}.
Therefore, v_x at t=4\text{ sec}:
v_x(\text{ at }t=4\text{ sec }) = v_x(\text{ at }t=2\text{ sec } ) + \Delta v_x = -3\text{ m/s}.

subsection.title: Constant Acceleration Motion
subsection.p: The one-dimensional kinematics for constant acceleration motion plays an important practical role. We are interested in a motion between two instants in time, t = t_i to t = t_f . We use the subscript i and f to denote quantities at these instants. The following diagram illustrates the setup.
We denote the interval by \Delta t = t_f - t_i , the change in position by \Delta x = x_f-x_i , and change in velocity by \Delta v_x = v_{f,x} - v_{i,x} .

They obey the following relations.
\amp \Delta v_x = a_x \Delta t. \amp \Delta x = v_{av,x} \Delta t,
where
v_{av,x} = \dfrac{v_{i,x} + v_{f,x}}{2}.
It is possible to eliminate \Delta t from these equations to obtain
v_{f,x}^2 = v_{i,x}^2 + 2 a_x \left( \Delta x \right)^2,
which we will refer to as the no-t-equation . It is also possible to eliminate v_{f,x} to obtain another useful equation
\Delta x = v_{i,x} \Delta t + \dfrac{1}{2}a_x\left(\Delta t \right)^2,
which we will refer to as the no-v_f-equation.

Some special motions require simplified analysis. For instance, if velocity is constant, then, in these equations
a_x = 0\ \ \ \ (\text{constant velocity case})

Another important special situation occurs when speed is constant during a motion. Speed at an instant is equal to the absolute value of the velocity at that instant, i.e., in one-dimensional situation, you would strip the sign of the velocity to get the speed at that instant. Even though you can get speed at an instant from the velocity at that instant, the average speed during an interval is not related to the average velocity over that interval due to the way averaging is done in the two cases.

Average speed to be denoted by the symbol v_{s,av} is totality of distance covered divided by the time taken. Thus, if you move from origin to x = 10 \text{ cm} and return to origin, you would actually cover a distance of 20 \text{ cm} even though your \Delta x = 0 since your initial x is the same as your final x. We denote the actual distance covered by the letter d . In constant speed motion following equations are used.
\amp |v_f| = |v_i| = v_{s,av} \amp d = v_{s,av} \, \Delta t

Sign conventions. We use a sign convention to follow the directions of velocity and acceleration. The source of these sign conventions will become clear after you learn vectors. The following diagrams clarify the sign assignments of velocity and acceleration.

p.p: The velocity v_x is positive if object is moving in the direction of positive axis and negative if in the opposite direction.
Acceleration a_x is positive in two situations: if either v_x is positive and speeding up OR v_x is negative and slowing down.
Acceleration a_x is negative in two situations: if either v_x is negative and speeding up OR v_x is positive and slowing down.
